content:
You really need a test case + validator that has the answer as a single digit but that the integers go up above 20.

This is because on shortest mode you can cheat and just search for the integers as substrings and still pass as it is.

I got beaten in shortest mode by someone who did this, but their code would fail a test like '0 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9 10', as their code would output 11 instead of 1.

I had test2 failing but got 100% on validation. Because I misinterpreted the description.

Please add a validation which does what test2 does.
This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "REVERSE" option has therefore been deactivated.

I just had this clash in shortest mode and all of us got 50% or less because none of the visible tests check the case where all numbers up to n are in the array. Validators 3, 5, and 6 do test for this.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Eazy and quick, pretty nice for CoC

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice challenge even though it might be a bit hard for reverse mode.
There should be a visible test case similar to either validator 3 or validator 4 to make it suitable for reverse mode.
Note to author: What does MEX mean? Maybe you would like to clarify the acronym.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Simple and easy to do.
Edited some of the formatting in the puzzle description, and changed "number" to "integer" for greater clarity.

I like the idea, but you need at least 3 more test cases for it to be adequate for reverse mode.

You should look at other submissions to see how to format this puzzle. The syntax is double brackets [[]] for variables, and you can check for others by clicking on the "?" icons next to each section when you edit. You should also change "numbers" to "integers."

Finally, it would be best to have the same number of integers between each test/validator pair, unlike the current Tests #3 and #4.

Thank you for the feedback I might need a little bit more info about what syntax you are actually talking about. 

Also, You it is a bit of an eye-sore having a testcase with anything more than 20 numbers and yet we definitely do need a testcase checking the bigger numbers. So just a few testcases can have different number of integers in validators and testcases. 

Any more changes are always welcome!
I think short testcases are more than enough to understand that we are actually looking for MEX of the list. The size does not matter.

All the outputs are smaller than 5 which makes it extremely likely there are multiple patterns that fit. For example "if the sum of inputs is divisible by 3, print 0, otherwise print the count of primes != 3 in range (0..inputs.sum)" passes all visible test cases. While that's not a pattern many people would go for, hopefully it illustrates my point that such patterns can and will be found when all of the visible outputs are small.
I did not see it that way.. I'll add a few cases for that.

If you write [[5]] instead of 5 in the prompt, the 5 will display highlighted in yellow. {{5}} makes it blue with a different font, and <<5>> is just bold. The formatting won't display unless you are in "Test in IDE" mode or on the submission page, but not during an edit.

To get more details, click on the "?" icon next to each section when you are editing.
Thank you somebody did it for me :P
